item.title: Authoring Content
item.description: All of the content in your Quartz should go in the /content folder. The content for the home page of your Quartz lives in content/index.md.

item.title: Building your Quartz
item.description: Once you’ve initialized Quartz, let’s see what it looks like locally: npx quartz build --serve This will start a local web server to run your Quartz on your computer.

item.title: Configuration
item.description: Quartz is meant to be extremely configurable, even if you don’t know any coding.

item.title: Citations
item.description: Quartz uses rehype-citation to support parsing of a BibTex bibliography file.

item.title: Docker Support
item.description: Quartz comes shipped with a Docker image that will allow you to preview your Quartz locally without installing Node.

item.title: LaTeX
item.description: Quartz uses Katex by default to typeset both inline and block math expressions at build time.

item.title: Mermaid Diagrams
item.description: Quartz supports Mermaid which allows you to add diagrams and charts to your notes.

item.title: Obsidian Compatibility
item.description: Quartz was originally designed as a tool to publish Obsidian vaults as websites.

item.title: OxHugo Compatibility
item.description: org-roam is a plain-text personal knowledge management system for emacs.
